Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: only traces of slip remaining; exterior: paired hook maeander pattern between pairs of narrow lines; below from left, part of pendant roundel, part of pendant triangle.
Producer name: Close to: Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl (according to Williams)
Attributed to: Group of the Aphrodite Bowl (according to Lemos)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.48.1894 and GR.50.1894. Lemos describes GR.48.1894 and GR.50.1894 as being in the style of the Würzburg chalices, but dated later than those chalices because she considers the style of the drawing to be debased and because of the elementary and isolated interior decoration. If so, then GR.49.1894 is also of the same style. However, it must be pointed out that Lemos places this sherd in the Mature Animal Style Williams suggests that the painter of this vessel also painted British Museum 1888,0601.475.g, 1888,0601.475.d and 1924,1201.115 and was closely related to the Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl.
Bibliographic references: Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 132 note 28)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 33, no. 22, pl. XVII)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 264, no. 564, pl. 71)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0378) (phase 2)
